<gene_function>
The *hisB* gene encodes imidazoleglycerol-phosphate dehydratase, a key enzyme in histidine biosynthesis. It catalyzes the sixth step of the pathway, converting imidazoleglycerol-phosphate to imidazoleacetol-phosphate. This enzyme is essential for de novo histidine production in bacteria. While no Prochlorococcus-specific studies were found, the gene's function is conserved across cyanobacteria and Gram-negative bacteria as part of the core histidine operon.

</gene_function>

<physiological_impact>
*hisB* inactivation leads to histidine auxotrophy, severely impairing growth in histidine-free environments. In nitrogen-limited conditions (relevant to the coculture study), histidine biosynthesis becomes critical as nitrogen is a major component of histidine (N-atoms constitute ~27% of its structure). Disruption of *hisB* would force dependence on exogenous histidine sources, altering cellular metabolism and growth kinetics.

</physiological_impact>
